qas.question: When do earlier approaches to translation lose relevance for historians?

context: Though <a0_0><b4_0>earlier approaches<b4_0/><a0_0/> to translation are less commonly used today, they retain importance when dealing with their products, as <a1_0><b5_0>when historians view ancient or medieval records<b5_0/><a1_0/> to piece together <a2_0><b6_0>events<b6_0/><a2_0/> which took place in non-Western or pre-Western environments. Also, though heavily influenced by Western traditions and practiced by translators taught in Western-style educational systems, Chinese and related translation traditions retain some <a3_0><b7_0>theories and philosophies<b7_0/><a3_0/> unique to the Chinese tradition.
